title: Entrusted
opening: Princess Elincia's newly-formed Crimean army, with Ike as its commander, marches to Tor Garen and claims its first victory. Tor Garen is a vast wall guarding Daein's border. Manned by battalions of well-trained soldiers, it was long thought impenetrable. Yet the strength of the Crimean army under General Ike's leadership far outstrips Daein's expectations, and Tor Garen falls. Learning of Gallia's increasing interest in the war, Ike wastes no time ordering his troops further into the heart of Daein. The gears of history, which had come to a halt with the fall of Crimea, slowly creak to life once more...

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: Naesala! King Naesala of Kilvas! I would speak with you now!

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: Oh, if it isn't General Petrine. What brings you up to these frosty mountain peaks?

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: I've no time for pleasantries. Is it true? Has Crimea's army breached Tor Garen?

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: Though I am loathe to report it, this appears to be the case.

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: Bah! Kayachey, you worthless dog! Being defeated by that girl's motley band just proves how useless he was.

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: Surely it's not the general's fault alone. He was told that Crimea's army was weak and that Tor Garen was impregnable. And yet...he was defeated. I'd say that someone severely underestimated our enemy. Wouldn't you?

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: What was that? Do you dare to insult Daein, crow? Men have forfeited their lives for less.

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: Insult Daein? Never! Come now, General Petrine. I'm merely stating the facts. Regardless of the previous battle's outcome, Crimea's army will be stopped here. I will be taking the field myself.

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: ...Hmph. Sounds like you've set the stage for a grand performance.

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: General Petrine, Kilvas will always stand at Daein's side... As long as we receive our payment, of course.

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: If gold is all it takes, then may our friendship never end. See to it that your performance warrants such consideration! Homasa! Come here!

intro.speaker: Homasa
intro.line: Yes.

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: Work with King Kilvas and put a stop to Crimea's army. No screw ups! Or else!

intro.speaker: Homasa
intro.line: Leave it to me, General.

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: I will not suffer another failure, King Kilvas. You must finish them, and do so quickly...Are we clear? Arrr! I am sick to death of being made a fool by that Crimean floozy and her pathetic band of sellswords!

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: And the remaining portion of my fee?

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: Don't worry, we have it ready. You'll get paid when the job is done.

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: As long as we're clear on that point, everything's settled. Well then, I'm off.

intro.speaker: Petrine
intro.line: Dog's breath! Even by half-breed standards, those crows are complete scum! Give that one even the smallest opening, and he'll steal the eyes from your skull. What an untrustworthy wretch.

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: So, General...there look to be a lot of enemy soldiers ahead. Mostly Daein, but there are some crows from Kilvas as well.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: More than our last fight?

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: Yeah, there's a lot, but the most troubling thing is that King Kilvas is with them.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: The crow king himself is cooperating with Daein?

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: Yep. And compared to the other crows, the king is in a class by himself. Obviously, he's no match for our king, but... Anyway, you should move carefully.

intro.speaker: Ulki
intro.line: ...General Ike. I hear the sound of many wings ahead. It would seem Kilvas soldiers have joined the troops of Daein for this fight.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Is Kilvas's contingent larger than the what we faced in the last battle?

intro.speaker: Ulki
intro.line: There are many... But what causes me more concern is the voice of King Kilvas.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: The king himself is cooperating with Daein?

intro.speaker: Ulki
intro.line: Yes. And compared to the other crows, the king is in a class by himself. We must be cautious.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: An entire unit under the command of King Kilvas? I think that bodes ill for us.

intro.speaker: Soren
intro.line: The outcome of the battle hinges on how we deal with them.

intro.speaker: Titania
intro.line: Kilvas soldiers, hm? As fellow bird tribe laguz, what can you tell us about them?

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: Please don't lump us together with those carrion birds.

intro.speaker: Ulki
intro.line: We're not partial...to the crows.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: As you know, we are outmanned by the Daein troops. Is there any way to get the ravens to withdraw? That would be a tremendous help.

intro.speaker: Janaff
intro.line: ...Well, suppose I could go meet with King Kilvas... If I had to. I don't think that my speaking to him is going to make a difference, though.

intro.speaker: Ulki
intro.line: If you like, we will try, but...Don't expect anything to come of it.

intro.speaker: Reyson
intro.line: No matter the circumstance, I will never again speak to a crow.

intro.speaker: Soren
intro.line: No matter what we decide, sitting here like this is giving the enemy more time to prepare.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: You're right. Come on, let's get moving!

intro.speaker: Daein Soldier
intro.line: Sir! The Crimean army has arrived!

intro.speaker: Homasa
intro.line: I hope they are prepared to pass into oblivion. For this will be their final resting place!

intro.speaker: Naesala
intro.line: Crimean stragglers joined with an army on loan from Begnion. I've even heard they have a betrayer in their midst. And yet they still march on... What an odd group. But as long as Kilvas stands at the side of Daein, they have no future. Ah, I suppose they're just unlucky.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: It appears the enemy has spotted us.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Well, a group this large is hard to miss.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: How will you proceed?

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: No tricks. Nothing fancy. We'll hit them from the front--fast and hard.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: I'm sure you're already aware of this, but if you don't do something about Kilvas, you're at a disadvantage.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Yes, I've heard about the ravens... But even so, it's not as if we can turn tail and run away.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: Now that I think on it, King Kilvas and Prince Reyson used to be close friends. Did you ask him to speak to the king?

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: He was most emphatic in his refusal. It seems that Naesala was responsible for Reyson's capture at the hands of Duke Tanas. I can't really blame him.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: And the hawks? They, too, are of the bird tribes. Surely some connection can be found there.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: They...weren't very excited about the suggestion.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: You could command them to do it.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: There's an antagonism between the tribes that we don't understand. I'd rather not force the issue. Trying to coerce them into it would be...unfair. I will let them do as they please.

intro.speaker: Nasir
intro.line: That is so very like you. However, giving orders that are unpopular is often necessary when one is in command, and--

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Maybe so. But I can only do things the best I know how. My own way.

intro.speaker: Ike
intro.line: Come, it's time to go!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: You...

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: King Kilvas! You egg-stealing snake.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: One of Tibarn's flock, eh? You are his eyes, if I'm not mistaken.

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: It's not enough that you sold the White Prince to humans? Now you're fighting against laguz?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: You hawks rescued Reyson didn't you? So everything worked out in the end! What's the problem?

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: I'd like you to repeat those words to the prince's face.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Reyson is here? HERE?! Why?!

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: He supports the Crimean army! The beorc leading this army helped him to escape Serenes Forest.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Helped him? Are you saying a human came to the aid of Reyson? A laguz?

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: Yes! And he rescued Princess Leanne, too!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Leanne...is alive?

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: Don't play the fool! You know the life of the forest has returned. That was their power at work.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: I see. That's how the forest...Of course.

battle-talk.speaker: Janaff
battle-talk.line: Listen up, crow! You need to fly over there and talk to the prince. If you don't do it, I'm gonna know that you really are the enemy and report that back to King Tibarn. Think it over!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Yes... Mmm...What to do.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: You...

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: King Kilvas. Why have you decided to make the laguz your enemy?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: One of Tibarn's flock, eh? You are his ears, if I'm not mistaken.

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: Why did you sell Prince Reyson to a beorc?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: You hawks rescued Reyson didn't you? So everything worked out in the end! What's the problem?

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: Would you repeat your words to Prince Reyson himself?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Reyson is here? HERE?! Why?!

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: The beorc leading this army helped him to escape Serenes Forest.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Helped him? Are you saying a human came to the aid of Reyson? A laguz?

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: That is what I say. He also rescued Princess Leanne.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Leanne...is alive?

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: She was asleep for all these years. The forest protected her. Their voices brought the forest back to life.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Of course, so that's how...

battle-talk.speaker: Ulki
battle-talk.line: Why don't you try speaking to Prince Reyson? If you do that, perhaps King Tibarn's rage will burn less brightly.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Tibarn's rage, eh? Hmm...Mmm...

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Reyson!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Hey, Reyson! Look at you! You look sharp, kid!

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Go...away...

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Oh, so you can talk.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: You... How dare you show your face to me!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Well, I have been called brazen before. Some have gone so far as to say shameless. Come on, at least let me give you a reason.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Begone! My ears are closed to you.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Reyson, we're friends, are we not?

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Oh, yes! Friends! In fact, we're such good friends that you sold me to that foul, bloated man!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: I didn't really sell you! Besides, I planned on rescuing you right away. You were just impatient and flew away on your own, so--

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Are you blaming me?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: No, no! Well, maybe... I mean...It was I who was in the wrong. On all accounts.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: No one was hurt in the end. Come on, smooth those ruffled feathers. All right?

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Leanne is alive.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Yes, Tibarn's attendant told me. That's wonderful news. When he sees her face, I'm sure King Lorazieh will begin to feel better at once. Things are really looking up, aren't they, Reyson?

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: ...I suppose that... If you hadn't deceived me and taken me to the forest... We might not have discovered her... So, I will forgive you. Just this once!

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Reyson! Oh, that's--

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: WITH...conditions. Will you accept them?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: ...What are they?

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Pull your troops from this battle. Now. And never again enter into combat against your fellow laguz.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Oh, come now, Reyson. That's asking too much--

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: What will you do, then? Will you continue to fight the Crimean army to which I'm in service?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Very well. You win, Reyson. I'll leave and take my soldiers with me. However, I cannot say what the future will bring. I have the fate of my nation to consider after all.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Hmm... Very well.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: So, we're friends again? Come to Kilvas for a visit, will you? Nealuchi will be so pleased.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: I'll do that. When this war is over, Leanne and I will both come.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Oh, and as for Tibarn...

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: I'll speak with him. There's no need for you to worry.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Thank you. Farewell. And watch yourself! This is war, you know?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Oh, I almost forgot. I've got something for you. Call it an I'm sorry present.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Eh? What's this supposed to be?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: It's a human trinket. It's called a knight ring.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Something made by beorc?

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Don't make such a disgusted face. I tried it, and it proved to be quite useful.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Understood. I'll take it for now.

battle-talk.speaker: Naesala
battle-talk.line: Don't get killed, Reyson. If anything were to happen to you... Nealuchi would never let me hear the end of it.

battle-talk.speaker: Reyson
battle-talk.line: Naesala... Thank you.

battle.speaker: Naesala
battle.line: Listen to me, darkwings! We of Kilvas are leaving. Turn at once and head for home.

battle.speaker: Daein Soldier
battle.line: I think abandoned would be more accurate, but--

battle.speaker: Homasa
battle.line: Idiot! It's the same thing! Aaaargh! Accursed sub-humans! We should never have trusted them.

boss.speaker: Homasa
boss.line: My sword is lightning! Do you think you can follow its dance?

recruit-battle.speaker: Naesala
recruit-battle.line: Oh ho! Black wings! Among humans these are considered bad omens, are they not? Then take these omens as fact, and let them herald you to the afterlife!

recruit-battle.speaker: Naesala
recruit-battle.line: N-no... This cannot be...Is this...my...fate? What of Kilvas--

recruit-battle.speaker: Naesala
recruit-battle.line: Guaa... I was careless...and you're better than expected. To me, my brethren! We leave at once!

end.speaker: Raven Laguz
end.line: King Naesala, the Daein army has been routed!

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: How nice. What a lot of braggarts they turned out to be. Very well, let us withdraw as well.

end.speaker: Raven Laguz
end.line: Are you sure? If we retreat now, what will General Petrine say?

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: Promises made to humans are worth less than a dead snake. Forget about her. Losing the remainder of our payment stings, but still... You can't buy your life back, can you?

end.speaker: Raven Laguz
end.line: Good point. Well made, sir.

end.speaker: Naesala
end.line: Fly, my darkwings! We return to Kilvas!

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: We won...somehow.

end.speaker: Nasir
end.line: It's because you did an excellent job of driving off the ravens.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Yeah, if we had continued to fight them, we would have suffered more casualties than this. I must extend thanks to Reyson.

end.speaker: Elincia
end.line: My lord Ike! I'm pleased to see you well. You haven't been injured, have you?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Princess Elincia. I'm fine. I'm unharmed.

end.speaker: Elincia
end.line: Oh, that's good...

end.speaker: Titania
end.line: Ike! May I have a word? And if you don't mind, Princess Elincia, would you join us as well? Please join me in that building.

end.speaker: Elincia
end.line: What could it be?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Let's go see.

end.speaker: Elincia
end.line: This is...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Holy...

end.speaker: Titania
end.line: Incredible, no? It's gold. All of it.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Daein must be filthy rich! There's so much, it doesn't even seem real. What do we do with it?

end.speaker: Soren
end.line: It's the spoils of war. So naturally, it's ours.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: In that case, I'd like to borrow fifty thousand. Would that be all right?

end.speaker: Titania
end.line: That's a lot of money. What are you planning on doing?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: It's a private matter...

end.speaker: Titania
end.line: I apologize, Commander. You're not a child. There's no reason for me to pry.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: No, if I may borrow the fifty thousand, that will be more than--

end.speaker: Titania
end.line: You won't borrow it, you'll accept it! And in good faith. The remainder we'll give to Soren for company maintenance. Would that be all right, Princess Elincia?

end.speaker: Elincia
end.line: Yes, of course.

end.speaker: Petrine
end.line: Grrr...

end.speaker: Daein Soldier
end.line: Um, General P-Petrine? P-please, General! I'm just a...m-messenger! H-however...I have to tell you--

end.speaker: Petrine
end.line: I already heard, you dunderhead! I hated those filthy crows right from the start. Even so, to be betrayed in such a fashion... Grrr... Someone will pay for this! Oh, you certainly had your way with us, didn't you, King Kilvas? But if you want to make an enemy of Daein, then so be it! Once Gallia's fallen, we'll turn our attention to your puny nation and wipe it off the face of the world!

end.speaker: Petrine
end.line: Why are you still there? Do you find me amusing?! Shall I make my lance dance for you?

end.speaker: Daein Soldier
end.line: N-no, ma'am! No! Never! N-not at all! I beg your pardon! So sorry... I'll be...going...now...

end.speaker: Petrine
end.line: Dog's breath! I need...something. A brilliant plan... If this continues much longer, the king will have my head.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: You wanted to see me?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: You've waited a long time. Take this. It's the gold you were promised.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Finally scraped it together, eh? I'll gladly accept it.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Aren't you going to count it?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: There's no need. I'll trust you.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: All right, then I'll take what was promised. The report you wrote for my father.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: There isn't one.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: There is no report. Never was.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: You lied to me? You exploited my need to know more about my father!?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: There is something I must tell you. However, it could not be written down. It is too great of a secret for that. Your father told me to wait until I thought you were mature enough to hear it, and then to tell you myself.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Mature? Then what was the fifty thousand gold for?!

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Ah, the gold. That was my idea. I thought it would be a good way to test how resourceful and responsible you were.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Get started. I want to hear it all.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: I've spent a long time as Greil's hired shadow. A long time. I remained hidden from sight in case the day ever arrived that I needed to fulfill my contract... All that time, for one job.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What was it?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: If Greil were ever to go berserk, I was to stop him. I was to take his life.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What?!

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Actually, there was one other thing. If Greil were ever slain by his pursuers... I was to watch over his son and tell him Greil's secret at an appropriate time. That was my job.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Berserk... What are you talking about? Why would you have to kill my father?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Because of Lehran's Medallion.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What medallion? What are you talking about?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: The medallion your sister carries.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Huh? That old bronze thing? I thought it was just a keepsake of my mother's... Are you telling me that it's something more?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Greil told me it was an object of great peril, but nothing more. I did some investigating on my own, though. And what I discovered...surprised me.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Tell me.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Lehran was one of the heron clan, an ancestor of our Prince Reyson, who  carried with him a bronze medallion. Long, long ago, a band of heroes defeated an evil god and imprisoned it therein.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: An evil god? Do you think this is funny? You ARE joking, aren't you?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Unfortunately, I'm not. And I've no idea how the cursed thing came to be in Greil's possession. That being said, I do know that the men who hunted your father were actually seeking the medallion. Why they wanted it and what they planned to do with it... Just thinking about it gives me chills.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: I'm finding all of this a little hard to believe. You said the medallion was an object of great peril, didn't you? Then why would my father allowMist to carry it around? That doesn't make any sense.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: It's because she can carry it safely. Actually, she's the only one who can. If you want proof, think back. Have you ever once touched it?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: ...No. I haven't. A long time ago, I remember reaching out for it while Mist had it in her hand... My father scolded me harshly. After that, I assumed...it was my sister's alone, and I never reached for it again.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Compared to other people, the balance within your sister is extremely strong. Your mother, it seems, was the same. That's why they could bear it safely. The medallion is like a strong poison. It takes the worst aspects of a person and magnifies them a thousandfold. Greil touched it only once, and it drove him to complete madness.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: So that's what you meant when you said he went berserk?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: That's right. Beorc and laguz are made up of two forces: balance and chaos. In this, there is no difference between us. It is the proportion of balance to chaos that determines how much the medallion affects a person. In that sense, it predicts how much harm that person might do.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Your father was one of the preeminent swordsmen of his generation. That day, after he touched the medallion...Twenty soldiers had come for him. Twenty highly trained killers. Your father barely broke a sweat cutting them down. Then he began attacking his neighbors, those who had taken him in, concealed his identity, and called him friend. He slew them one by one, until your mother rushed in...thinking only to save her husband from himself.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: It was over in an instant. Your mother grabbed the medallion from his hand and stepped away from him...They say she smiled as he pulled his sword from her breast and forgave him as her life's blood spilled into the street.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: My father...killed my mother? No. That can't be...

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: It was the medallion. Its power is too great for any man. Even one of your father's caliber. Me? You? If either of us touched it, I'm certain that we both would have been consumed by madness. When your father regained his senses, he tracked me down. It seems he'd heard rumors of me some time before. He said he had need of someone like me: closemouthed, skilled, and most importantly, willing to do any sort of work. Of course, after hearing what he wanted me to do, I turned him down. Greil was once a famed general... He was Sir Gawain, one of Daein's Four Riders, and I recognized him at once. There was no chance someone like me would ever be able to stop him.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: But you took the job anyway...Why did you change your mind?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Greil had lost his wife, and his grief was overpowering. To keep anything like that from happening again, he crippled himself. He slashed the tendons in his sword hand so that he could not wield a sword again. I took the job only because he had become someone my skill could handle. And even then, he was still far stronger than most men...

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: I... I don't know what to say...

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: That is Greil's secret, as I know it. I now entrust to you the responsibility of seeing that the medallion does not fall into the wrong hands. Your sister must keep it.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: ...As my father lay dying, he told me to forget everything and live in peace. What did he mean?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: He didn't want you to lose yourself and go hunting for revenge, I suppose. He was killed much, much sooner than he ever expected to be.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: So my father's dying wish was for me to protect the medallion? If I can do that, everything will be all right?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: I believe so. At the very least, that must take precedent over everything else.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: I understand.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Well then, my work here is done.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Whatever you decide to do now is up to you.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: If I call, can I count on your assistance again?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: If I'm not busy with anything else, I might agree to work for you again. Farewell.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Father...

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Oh, one last thing.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: What is it?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: Do you want to hire me? In the event that you go berserk someday? If we make a deal now, you won't have to worry about it anymore. As for payment... I can take it out of the fifty thousand you just gave me. What do you say?

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Please.

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: That's a wise decision....And in that case, I no longer need to conceal my true identity.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Huh?

end.speaker: Volke
end.line: I'm not really a thief. I'm an assassin. From now on, I'll take on any job you've got, no matter how...dirty.

end.speaker: Ike
end.line: Father... Mother......Oh, why...

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Bye. See ya later!

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: Yep. Oh, Mist! Watch your step! It's slippery...

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Whooooa!

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: Mist!

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Ow! I landed right on my butt! Hee hee! This snow's cold!

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: Be careful!

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: All righty! Hey, watch, Jill! I'm gonna make a snow angel! Wheeee!

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: ...It must be nice to be so cheerful.

conversation.speaker: Unknown
conversation.line: Jill!

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: ...Who's there?

conversation.speaker: Haar
conversation.line: It's me.

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: Captain Haar? B-but...This is an enemy camp!

conversation.speaker: Haar
conversation.line: I've been trying to track you down ever since you disappeared at Toha. I figured you were off chasing after the Crimeans. I never imagined that you would join up with them.

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: At first, it was just circumstance, but... But now it's different. Now I'm with them because I want to be. Spending time with them--and coming into contact with laguz--has shown me what a fool I've been.

conversation.speaker: Haar
conversation.line: Laguz? I never thought I would hear that word from someone who once said sub-human with such absolute hatred. Sounds like you've had some good experiences with this happy little band.

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: I knew that if anyone would understand, it would be you, Captain.

conversation.speaker: Haar
conversation.line: So you're forming your own set of values for the first time. That's good. That's very, very good. But what are you planning to do now? If you keep moving forward, you're going to face General Shiharam before long.

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: Causing trouble for my father was never my intent. However...As a member of this army, I will face him with my shoulders straight and my head held high.

conversation.speaker: Haar
conversation.line: So you're determined to see this through?

conversation.speaker: Jill
conversation.line: I am!

conversation.speaker: Haar
conversation.line: So be it. Then there's nothing left to be said. Farewell. The next time we meet, it will be as enemies. Prepare yourself... And get some rest! You know how important it is.

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: Ike? Can I talk to you? A few minutes ago, a man I've never seen before showed up and spoke to Jill. I wasn't sure what was going on, so I went and found you. W-what should we do? Whatever they're talking about, it sure looks serious!

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Jill trained in the Daein army. Fighting against her countrymen will be tough...No matter how prepared she thinks she is.

conversation.speaker: Mist
conversation.line: I don't care what happens! You can't let her fight against her own father! All right, Ike?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Hmmm. It might not be a bad idea to keep her at the base camp...Just while we're in Daein.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: What do you think, guys? Are we going to be able to perform a new special attack?

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: I think we might. I was looking through some old scrolls on fighting techniques, and I found one that looks perfect.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Awesome! Nice work!

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: What is it?! What is it!? Come on, tell us how it works!

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: Well, if we want to learn it, there are some things we'll have to do.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Aw, dang! I hope it's not all technical, 'cause I won't be able to keep up. Just summarize it, will you?

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: I can do that. All right, the most important thing is we all have to use the same weapon. So, if all three of us can use a bow, that'll be one problem out of the way.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: A bow? You and I have to use bows?

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: Boyd, are you even listening to me? Yes, we all have to use the same weapon. That's part of the deal.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Crud! Nothing we can do about it, I guess. You better not slow us down, Rolf! You little brat.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Stop calling me a brat! I'm a better archer than you! If anyone slows us down, it'll be you, Boyd!

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: What did you say? I'm gonna--

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: Knock it off, Boyd! Your skills with a bow aren't as polished as Rolf's. Anyone can see that. Which means that even if Rolf has some natural skill, whoever taught him the fundamentals was an expert archer...

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Yeah, I know, but he just keeps blabbering this nonsense about how he taught himself.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: I... I did teach myself! I'm a prodigy.

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: Well, judging by your stance and the way you hold the bow, I think we all know the real story.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Eeep!

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Huh? What is it? What real story?!

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Oscar! No! Shhh!

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: ...The story... That Rolf's lucky to have a genius like me for a brother, that's what.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Aw, stop messing around. This is getting stupid.

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Whew...

conversation.speaker: Unknown
conversation.line: What're you guys talking about?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: The three of you have been huddled up here for a while now. What are you scheming?

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Shh! Um... Uh... Hi, Ike!

conversation.speaker: Oscar
conversation.line: Scheming is such an ugly word! We're just--

conversation.speaker: Rolf
conversation.line: Oh, hey, Ike! We're working on this special man--

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Yaaaaaaaaa!

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Gaaa...I forgot something...

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Oooo...gotta go...

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Sorry about that, Ike. He's been acting a bit odd these days.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Really? Seems to me that you're the odd one in the bunch.

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Um, sure, all right! Do us a favor, though, and make sure the three of us are all in the next battle.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Sure, I guess that's fine. But why?

conversation.speaker: Boyd
conversation.line: Well, it's a surprise. That's all. We'll show you later! I'm sure you'll like it! Come on! We can't be standing around all day. Let's go! Oscar! Rolf!

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Special man? Hmm... Man......Mandolin?...Manicotti?...Manifesto? Oh, who cares?

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: Brrr... I'll take on any number of enemies, but this snow is another story! I think my beautiful wings are icing over.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: That sounds like trouble. Are you going to be able to fly?

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: ...Yes, of course I can fly. These wings aren't for looks, you know? They're made of flesh and blood and feathers. It's not like I'm some animal that has to hibernate when winter rolls in. Sheesh! Can't you beorc tell the difference between comic exaggeration and serious conversation?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Um... Oh, I was supposed to laugh, was I? Sorry about that.

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: Oh, my...such sincerity. This is unexpected. It looks like someone taught you manners.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Er...

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: By the way, I've been meaning to ask...What are our chances for victory?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: We're still at an extreme disadvantage.

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: What? That's not the answer I wanted! You gotta do better than that, beorc general! I'm here! If we lose, how am I ever going to show my face in Phoenicis again?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: We're at a disadvantage, but I don't intend to lose. There's a man in Daein that I need to find...and I will be the last thing that he sees.

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: Ha ha! Well said! I wish you could repeat that to today's younger generation. There are some weaklings back home that I don't even want to call hawks. I'd love to stick 'em back in their eggs and start over from scratch.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Hey, you hatch from eggs?! Eh?

conversation.speaker: Janaff
conversation.line: I was speaking figuratively. You know? Like...a metaphor? We haven't hatched from eggs for many generations now. Silly beorc... All right, I'm outta here. I gotta warm up the ol' wings before battle, or who knows what might happen.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: I figured that egg thing was a joke, but I had no idea it ever really happened...Bird tribes... Go figure.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Excuse me, do you have a moment?

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: ...Oh. General Ike. What is it?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: It's nothing really...I just thought I'd say hello.

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: That's...considerate.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Um... Your king is very generous, isn't he? And it's not just Reyson I'm talking about. He left us his two retainers as well.

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: ...How do we pertain to the king's generosity?

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: I guess it's because Reyson kept apologizing... I just thought that... Am I misinterpreting something?

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: I...don't know. But I know that the king can survive without our help.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: Is that true? That's pretty amazing. I've been given the title of lord, but I still can't run this army on my own. Titania and Soren handle all the little details, and that's what keeps us from collapsing into chaos.

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: Our king...does nothing special. Everyone just does what's needed. There is no chaos.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: He's really trusted, isn't he?

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: That's...natural. In laguz society, the strongest become king. Unlike the beorc, kingship is not tied to blood, so we have no weak kings. I'm sorry... Perhaps that was improper.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: No, I agree with you. Choosing a ruler by strength instead of birth makes much more sense.

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: When we face Begnion troops, we target the units with weak leadership and eliminate them first. Beorc weapons can be very powerful, but not everyone wields them well. Since beorc also choose generals by bloodlines, their competency is uneven...and that is a weakness of beorc armies. As for you, General Ike, the time to prove yourself is approaching.

conversation.speaker: Ike
conversation.line: It's true. No matter how strong the individuals are, that strength is worthless if they're weak as a unit. An army's power comes from leadership and management... That's good to remember. Thanks.

conversation.speaker: Ulki
conversation.line: Mmm.
